The Company expects its crew members to:

  • Comply with all company policies and procedures
  • Keep and promote a high standard of discipline and behaviour
  • Promote good working and social relations on board

Misconduct may lead to disciplinary measures, relative to the severity of the offence. Crew members may only be dismissed for minor offences if they repeat them.

Note  It is essential in a case of dismissal that the same or very similar offence has been committed by the same crew member.

List of minor offences

  • Unsatisfactory performance
  • Failure to be punctual
  • Absence from work/place of duty without satisfactory reason
  • Offensive and /or disorderly behaviour
  • Poor housekeeping
  • Minor act of negligence or disobedience
  • Minor neglect of duty
  • Excessive noise in common areas and alleyways

List of major offences

  • Assault
  • Harassment or bullying
  • Endangering any person or the ship
  • Smoking in prohibited areas
  • Use of naked flame or unapproved electric flashlight in prohibited areas
  • Wilful damage to the ship or property
  • Disobedience of orders relating to safety/security
  • Persistent / wilful failure to perform duty
  • Sleeping on duty or failure to remain on duty
  • Unjustified obstruction or delay of any ship operations
  • Unlawful possession or distribution of drugs
  • Possession of weapons
  • Theft or possession of stolen property
  • Possession of contraband
  • Breach of the ship board Drug and Alcohol Policy
  • Breach of the Company's Environmental Policy
  • Breach of local laws or terminal rules
  • Violation of Flag or Port State requirements
  • Bringing unauthorised persons, equipment, software and reading material on board
Note Major offences may result in termination of employment and possible legal action by authorities.

Personal fines

Crew members are personally liable for all legal fines imposed upon them for breach of local regulations by:

  • Customs’ Authorities
  • Immigration Authorities
  • Any law enforcement agencies

The Master may advance the amount of the fine provided the crew member’s wage account balance is sufficient. The crew member must submit a written request for payment on his / her behalf. This request must state that the crew member agrees to the deduction of the amount from his / her wage account.

The Master must inform the Company of the circumstances of the fine.

Travel Entitlement

Prior to departure, crew may receive cash allowance to cover travel expenses. The Company decides on the amount and provides the crew member with a letter stating the amount to be deducted from the wage account. Crew member must present this letter to the Master.

The Company arranges accommodation and transportation to the ship via the local port agents.

Provisioning

The crew is entitled to receive well balanced meals of sufficient quality and quantity. This will be provided free of charge during the period of engagement by the Company. As far as possible ships will be provided with adequate fresh provisions of milk, tea, coffee, vegetables and fruits.

Personal Hygiene Items

Bath soaps and washing powder for personal hygiene and washing of clothes are supplied to the crew by FFM. Requisitions are made under the cabin stores category.

Crew mail

Family may forward a crew member’s personal letters to the crewing office for transfer to the ship. The Company will not forward parcels or packages. Letters must clearly state “Crew Mail” on the envelope.

Crew members may pass outgoing letters to the port agent via the Master. Expenses are deducted from the crew member’s wage account. Crew members must arrange courier mail, parcels or packages themselves; the Master will not forward these.

3.1.1 Anti-Bullying, Harassment, Violence and Discrimination Procedure

Introduction

This procedure applies to all crew members of Flex LNG Fleet Management (“FFM”). This procedure sets out the minimum standards of behaviour required of our crew members to ensure an inclusive and safe environment free from harassment, violence, discrimination, bullying, and retaliation on FFM vessels. This procedure outlines crew members' personal responsibilities and provides information on what crew members should do should they need to raise a complaint related to a breach of this procedure.

FFM treats every crew member with respect and dignity and is committed to creating an inclusive workplace where diversity is valued. We will not tolerate bullying, discrimination, violence, or harassment of any kind based on gender, race, colour, religion, disability, political opinion, sexual orientation, national origin, trade union membership or any additional status protected by international law and/ or internationally accepted standards.

Every crew member has the right to work in an environment that is free from prejudice, bias, offensive and inappropriate behaviour. Discrimination, harassment, violence, bullying, and retaliation can damage crew member morale, confidence, competence, and performance, not just for the individual who experiences it but for those that witness the impact of the behaviour. It can also negatively impact on FFM’s reputation and create a legal risk for crew members and FFM.

FFM as a global company commits to respecting international human rights standards and adopting global procedures that apply to all workplaces. Even when global procedures may differ from local legal requirements, we still expect our crew members to adhere to our global procedures and standards.

Please seek guidance from the Captain or the Designated Person Ashore (hereinafter referred to as DPA) when in doubt. This procedure should be used in partnership with:

  • FFM Complaint Procedure
  • MLC Complaint Procedure MLC Complaint Tracking form
  • ICS – ITF Guidance On Eliminating Shipboard Harassment and Bullying

Please note that local procedures should also be used in conjunction with this procedure. Local procedures may provide specific definitions and courses of action to take based on local legislation. Where local legislation sets out higher standards than this procedure, the local legislation should be followed in addition to this procedure. In FFM locations where local legislation does not cover discrimination, harassment, retaliation, and bullying, this procedure should be followed.

Roles and Responsilities

All crew members have a personal responsibility to make themselves aware of and uphold the standards in this procedure. All crew members are encouraged to speak out against harassment, violence, discrimination, and bullying. Where it is safe to do so, crew members can support the victim and to address harassment, violence, discrimination, and bullying as soon as possible.

It is the responsibility of the crew on the vessel to prevent and report any unlawful act. Senior Officers are responsible for preventing and reporting harassment, violence, bullying, and discrimination and taking action when it is safe for them to do so, and to stop it where it has occurred.

We expect our Senior Officers to lead by example and role model inclusive behaviour. Senior Officers must recognize that their behaviour, what they say, what they choose to challenge, and what they choose to accept will often set the tone for the crew members they lead. 

Purpose / Objective

The intended outcome of this procedure is to:

  1. Set out the minimum standards of behaviour required of our crew members globally to ensure an inclusive environment free from harassment, violence, discrimination, bullying, and retaliation at FFM.
  2. Ensure that our crew members understand their personal responsibilities for upholding the standards set for our work environment.
  3. Provide our crew members with information on what to do should they need to raise a complaint related to a breach of this procedure. 

Scope

This procedure is intended to prohibit all improper and/or unlawful discrimination and harassment in the work environment on all FFM-managed vessels.

This also applies at business trips, training courses, company-sponsored, or client-sponsored business and social functions, or in the use of FFM resources, including electronic mail, the Internet, and social media. FFM crew members are required to completely refrain from unlawful discrimination and harassment, including sexual harassment, discriminatory harassment, and other conduct prohibited by law, even when outside of the work environment.

This procedure applies to all crew members of FFM and third parties onboard our vessels. This procedure underpins and should be used in conjunction with other FFM procedures.

Definitions

Harassment

Harassment includes but is not limited to, any improper, inappropriate and / or unwelcome behaviour that might reasonably be expected or be perceived to cause offence or humiliation to another person. Harassment may take the form of words, gestures or actions which tend to annoy, alarm, abuse, demean, intimidate, belittle, humiliate, or embarrass another or which create an intimidating, hostile or offensive work environment.

Sexual harassment

Sexual harassment includes, but is not limited to, unwelcome or uninvited behaviour of a sexual nature which is offensive, embarrassing, intimidating, or humiliating. Sexual harassment can be suffered by anyone.

Race, Ethnicity, or National Origin based harassment

Race, ethnicity, or national origin harassment and discrimination includes, but is not limited to, behaviour that intimidates, humiliates, ridicules, or undermines the confidence of a person by reason of a person’s race, ethnicity, colour, nationality, ethnic or national origin.

Specific examples of racial harassment include offensive behaviour by one person that may humiliate another person due to their race.

Violence

The term “violence and harassment” in the world of work refers to a range of unacceptable behaviours and practices, or threats thereof, whether a single occurrence or repeated, that aim at, result in, or are likely to result in physical, psychological, sexual, or economic harm, and includes gender-based violence and harassment.

The term “gender-based violence and harassment” means violence and harassment directed at persons because of their sex or gender or affecting persons of a particular sex or gender disproportionately and includes sexual harassment.

Bullying

Bullying includes but is not limited to, behaviour that mistreats others and causes either physical or emotional harm. Bullying can be verbal, non-verbal, psychological, and physical humiliation.

Examples of bullying and harassment can range from extremes such as violence, to less obvious forms, such as ignoring someone. Harassment or bullying can be direct (i.e., face to face) or indirect (i.e., voicemail, text, messaging, email)

Discrimination

Discrimination includes, but is not limited to, the practice of treating one person or group of people less fairly or less well than other people, based on: ethnicity, colour, sex, disability, age, religion, political opinion, nationality, sexual orientation, or social origin (among other characteristics).

Retaliation

For the purposes of this procedure, FFM considers retaliation to include but is not limited to, treating a person less favorably than others because that person has complained in good faith that someone has violated FFM’s Values and procedures or procedures. For the purposes of this procedure, this would specifically be a complaint made in good faith that someone has been violent, bullying, discriminating against them, or harassing them. It can also apply to treating a person less favorably than others because that person has supported someone to make the complaint or given evidence in relation to the complaint. Examples of this could include but are not limited to, isolating or ignoring someone because they have made a complaint in good faith or supported someone to make a complaint.

Breaches

Violation of this procedure may result in disciplinary actions.

We realize that it may be difficult to raise what can be very sensitive and hurtful issues, however, we encourage anyone who has experienced or witnessed behaviour that breaches the standards outlined in this procedure to report it to the company as described below under “Complaint procedures”.

We all have a responsibility to help uphold the standards set out in the procedure.

FFM will ensure that:

  • Breaches of this procedure will be taken seriously
  • Complaints are handled promptly and with care
  • All parties involved are treated objectively and fairly
  • Management will display the necessary discretion and protection of the dignity, safety and privacy of all parties involved
  • Appropriate action will be taken, where relevant, to ensure that the behaviour reported is ended

This procedure aims to ensure that reports and investigations are handled in ways that are inclusive, fair, gender-sensitive and support the human rights of the victim. If you have any doubts as to whether a breach has occurred or need any guidance, you are encouraged to seek advice. You can do this through the Master or the DPA.

Complaint Procedures

Any crew member who has experienced or witnessed behaviour that breaches this procedure should report the incident to either of the following:

  • MLC Crew Complaint Procedures  MLC Complaint Tracking form
  • DPA

In some instances, FFM has a legal obligation to report breaches to the appropriate enforcement authorities.

Any individual who has condoned, participated, authorised, or concealed any actions that breach this procedure will also be subject to disciplinary action.

3. Marine Personnel 

3.2 Recruitment and Retention 

Recruitment principle

FFM is an equal opportunities employer with a non-discrimination policy, based on gender, race, colour, religion, ethnic origin, gender identity, sexual orientation, or any other characteristic protected under applicable federal, state or local law.

Standard Operational Manning

Assumptions

Minimum Safe Operational Manning is recommended under regular operating conditions on board the vessels. Extraordinary conditions or irregularities which create additional workload outside or in addition to the vessel design are not regarded as regular operating conditions. Work and rest are defined to be considered within any 24 hours and any 7 working days (168 hours). Contract lengths are 3 months 1:1 rotation system for officers, and 8 months for ratings.

The core philosophy in the manning of a LNGC are as a traditional trading gas carrier with a full maritime crew on board. The age of the vessel is not taken into account under the recommendation of minimum operational manning. However, the Flex LNG fleet consist of a modern fleet with vessels built from 2018.

Summary

This document should be used as a tool to set the recommended minimum operational manning on the Flex LNG vessels in accordance with ISM Code § 6.2.2. Minimum operational manning is recommended by evaluating the operations the vessels are performing. The evaluation leading to the recommendation for minimum operational manning is the summary of sufficient manning to keep watches on deck (Bridge/CCR) and in engine (ECR) plus sufficient manning to perform the identified operations each vessel is delivering and be in compliance with flag state requirements and other industry standards. The vessels are sailing worldwide and most of the voyages the vessels are engaged in are more than 7 days between ports and relatively low to medium frequency of cargo operations per annum. LNGC operations are identified to deep sea navigation between ports and cargo operations and the minimum operational manning is identified to be 27 positions. Training/Cadets/fleet expansion double positions are excluded. If a vessel is engaged in a charter which requires regular STS or constant movement within High Risk Areas, the manning level will be revised in cooperation with the shipboard management.

LNGC organization

The shipboard Management Team (SMT) consists of the Master, Chief Officer, Chief Engineer, 2nd engineer, Cargo Engineer and SETO.

The vessels are organized conventionally with watch arrangement for navigation and for port (loading/discharging). The watch arrangement during navigation includes navigators on the bridge in a 4-8 watch plan using 3 junior officers. Chief Officer is day man. The engine room in E0 during navigation at Master and Chief Engineer discretion and Flex LNG procedures in QDMS

  • Bridge Manning Levels & Bridge Watchkeeping Arrangements
  • Engine Room Manning Levels & Engine Room Operations

For port operations (loading/discharging) the watch arrangement must comply with Flex LNG procedures and ISPS requirement documented in Ship Security Plan.

Recommended Minimum Safe Operational Manning

The recommended minimum safe operational manning should be the same on all vessels. 

Note:   Discuss any proposed changes to the standard operational manning with the fleet manager.

Choosing candidates

Any newly recruited seafarer must meet the minimum competence outline in the table below before joining a ship. Check for any additional flag state requirements.

Refer to FFM Training Matrix

Discuss with the fleet team if the candidate does not meet the minimum rank experience.

All Certificates must be in the official language of the issuing country and must include a translation into English.

Age limits

No seafarer under 18 years of age will be employed by FFM.

The normal retirement age is 65 years. Obtain approval from the Fleet Manager to employ someone over this age.

Oil major requirements

Caution: Discuss any potential non-compliance with the Fleet Management team before arranging crew change.

Oil majors are a group of multinational oil companies given this title due to their size, age or market position. The chartering department employs tankers to carry cargo on behalf of oil majors.

Some oil majors/charterers have specific combined experience requirements for ship’s crew carrying their cargo or trading to their terminals. Confirm specific requirements with Flex Operations department. If charterer have no specific requirements, apply OCIMF Officer Matrix.

There must be a minimum of 14 days between the sign-on dates for:

  • Master and Chief Officer
  • Chief Engineer and 2nd Engineer

Cadets, assistants and junior officers

Responsibilities

The Head of Crewing responsible for the FFM cadet programme.

The Fleet Personnel Officer is responsible for Cadet planning, in close co-ordination with Head of Crewing.

C/O is the company’s assigned Training Officer. The C/O will sign the Deck Cadet training book and the 2/E or C/E will sign the Engine Cadet training book. 

Management of training positions

3. Marine Personnel

3.3 Promotion 

Promotion Criteria
Note :  

 Gas Engineer promotion options will be assessed based on qualifications.

Newly Promoted Masters and Chief Engineers

The first full tour of duty for newly promoted Masters and Chief Engineers is a probationary period during which they are mentored and monitored by FFM office. They are also mentored and monitored by the off- signing Master or Chief Engineer during the recommended handover period.

Promotions initiated on board

The Master:

  1. Verifies that crew member meets promotion criteria
  2. Sends recommendation to FPO
  3. Obtains written approval from FPO prior to effecting the promotion
  4. Updates crew list
  5. Notifies FPO of time and date of promotion
Note In urgent circumstances, promotions are possible without fulfilling all promotion criteria. These are temporary promotions only.

Trainee Role

FFM will have a few selected trainee roles in the fleet to prepare for the future needs of Senior Officers.

The rank as Master Trainee and Chief Engineer Trainee shall have completed all promotion requirements prior to approval of Trainee Rank and shall be approved by FFM as per promotion procedure to Master and Chief Engineer.

It is expected that the Trainee is ready for promotion to a higher rank and is available to join a vessel should there be a vacancy of short notice. It is the responsibility of the Trainee to ensure he is engaged in the duties for the higher rank and takes continuous responsibility for his competence development. The Trainee shall have a contract as a trainee in the next rank, but the job description and duties remain the same as Chief Officer or 2nd Engineer.

Time onboard as a Trainee does not count towards matrix time for higher rank. 

Article No:303 / Rev No:045/Effective Date:22-09-2023/Approved By: Admin

3. Marine Personnel Manual (SHIIP)

3.4 Appraisal Guidelines
Note   Use Crewing PAL for carrying out all appraisals.

Responsibilities

  • Chief Officer appraises the Deck Officers and Deck Ratings in consultation with the Master. Master adds his comments
  • 2nd Engineer appraises the Engine Officers and Engine Ratings in consultation with the Chief Engineer. Chief Engineer adds his comments
  • 2nd Engineer appraises the Gas Engineer, Gas Assistant, Gas Engineer Cadet in consultation with the Chief Engineer and Chief Officer. Chief Engineer will add combined comments for himself and Chief Officer
  • ETO appraises the ETO Cadet. Chief Engineer adds his comments
  • Chief Engineer appraises the Second Engineer and ETO
  • Master appraises  Chief Officer and Galley staffand inititates the appraisel for chief engineer
  • Marine Superintendents (MSI) appraises the Master
  • Technical Superintendents (TSI) appraises the Chief Engineer

Newly Promoted Masters and Chief Engineers

The new end of contract appraisal system is designed to examine the competency and capability of all officers. This includes those newly promoted. The appraisal consists of a self-appraisal by the newly promoted Master / Chief Engineer that is reviewed in the office. The office provides a comparison to the appraisee. Every point of difference is explained to enable the Master / Chief Engineer to benefit and continue improving during the next contract. Once signed off the appraisal is locked and retained in PAL. 

Shipboard appraisal process

  1. Appraiser and appraisee:
    • Hold a joint meeting
      • Quarterly - at the end of each quarter
      • Final - prior to sign off
      • Upon special request
Note   The quarterly appraisal is optional if appraiser and appraisee have sailed together for less than 1 month.
  • Discuss:
  • Performance, attitude and conduct
  • Strengths and weaknesses
  • Methods for improvement
  • Training needs / requests
  1. Appraiser and appraisee add their comments in PAL
  2. Appraiser and appraisee sign the printed appraisal
  3. Master:
    • Submits appraisal to FPO in PAL
    • Gives a signed hard copy to the crew member
Note   

Appraisals are confidential and should only be seen by the appraiser, appraisee, and shore staff.

Shore involvement in shipboard appraisal

  1. Check appraisal is completed in PAL:
    • At the end of each quarter
    • Prior to sign of
  1. Review appraisal content:
    • Compare low-scoring appraisals to previous results
  1. Action any requests for:
    • Training
    • Promotion
  1. Discuss low scoring appraisals with Head of Crewing and fleet management team:
    • Highlight any areas of concern
    • Record any areas of concern and close-out actions in the communications tab of Seafarer details in PAL

Enhanced appraisal of senior officers

Master, Chief Officer, Chief Engineer, 2nd Engineer, Gas Engineer and SETO are subject to an enhanced appraisal process.

The Fleet Personnel Officer must:

9) Ensure final appraisal completed at the end of every contract

10) Advise sign off date. Receive completed form

11) Upload form in PAL

12) Action any requests for training

13) Arrange payment of performance bonus when officer re-joins

3. Marine Personnel

3.6 On-signing and Off-signing  

Crew Change 

The Master:

  1. Informs the Fleet Personnel Officer (FPO) within 24 hours via email of crew change stating:
    • Name
    • Rank
    • Date
    • Place
    • Any on board promotion
  1. Ensures:
    • Joining crew sign on the articles of agreement according to flag requirements
    • Disembarking crew sign off the articles of agreement according to flag requirements
    • Disembarking crew have provided a date of availability (DoA) and agreed to next assignment
  1. Issues a record of sea service to off-signers
Caution: Do not release the off-signing officer or crew in case the joining member is not correctly certified. Contact Fleet Personnel Officer and release the off-signer only after finding a satisfactory solution.
Note   Do not include any information about the crew member’s performance in the record of sea service.
  1. Ensures that crew sign “Sign off Environmental Pledge” and sends scanned copy to FPO
  2. Ensures update of:
    • Crew list
    • National Document Status
    • Flag State Document Status

Crew Change - System Handover

Note This is part of the Master Handover procedure whenever a change of command takes place.
  • Continue Numbering
  1. Outgoing Master provides a full list of accounts and passwords to incoming Master:
    • Master, email, PAL, all user computers
    • Email system
    • PAL/PMS system
    • iCafe dashboard
    • Administration accounts on any equipment
  1. Outgoing Master briefs incoming Master about operation of IT systems:
  1. PAL suite
    • Owner supplied PMS if different from PAL
    • Email
    • Computer equipment
    • Software
    • Network
    • Internet access
  1. Record handover on form SMM 23

Validity of documents

  1. Master ensures all crew have valid documents:
    • Passport and visas
    • Certificate of Competency (CoC) and other required licences
    • Valid endorsement
    • Original and Valid contract / SEA
    • Flag State documents
    • Medical certificates including drug and alcohol test
    • Vaccination certificate
    • Other STCW certificates as required
Note  The crew member is responsible for ensuring that their documents are valid for three months beyond contract duration.

Travel entitlements

The crew member must:

  1. Obtain air ticket from CSC
  2. Check:
    • Custom regulations
    • Airline baggage allowance
Note  Crew member must pay for excess baggage.
  1. Keep all original receipts when travelling
  2. Claim reimbursement of travel expenses through the Seafarer Portal
    • Claim expenses individually per receipt
    • Choose the correct expense category when filing expenses claims
    • Attach electronic copy of the receipt to support the claim

Lost baggage

  1. Crew member must:
    • Report loss to the airline immediately
    • Obtain lost luggage form from the airline
    • Inform port agents
    • Give lost luggage form to port agents
    • Request cash from agent or Master for purchase of essential items, as required: (Officers: USD 300   Ratings: USD 250)
    • Keep original receipts
    • Give receipts to the Master
    • Return unused cash to the Master
Note  For luggage lost on the way home, the above procedure does not apply. Crew member must follow up with the airline directly.

Family carriage

Note Officers’ spouse and up to two dependent children may sail with the ship, subject to approval. Children can sail only if the ship has suitable LSA. The Officer bears all expenses and agrees to the deduction from their wage account.
  1. Officer must obtain approval from:
    • Master
    • Fleet Manager
    • Owners
Caution: The Company does not permit family on board when transiting IBF High Risk Areas.
  1. Prior to joining, family members must:
    • Sign the Indemnity Form
    • Have:
      • Personal insurance covering accident / sickness / injury including repatriation in event of sickness, injury and / or death
      • A valid medical certificate
      • Non-pregnancy certificate for females
      • A valid vaccination certificate for trading area
      • A valid passport (children must have separate passports)
      • Visas as required
      • A joining letter from FFM
      • Comply with local requirements

  2. Master:

    • Collects passports and retains until family disembarks
    • Ensures:
      • On board safety familiarisation is conducted for all family members within 8 hours or prior to sailing

      • A familiarisation checklist has been signed by each family member

Note Refer to the on board familiarisation procedures.
  • Records number of additional meals served in the Rations Report
  • Informs SMC of embarkation and disembarkation

The presence of family members must never interfere with the safe, efficient, and secure operation of the ship. Family joining is subject to the Master’s approval, who must consider:

  • Lifeboat capacity
  • Limits of safety equipment certificate
  • Availability of LSA
  • Number of persons already on board
  • Likelihood of carrying additional personnel (technicians, inspectors, auditors etc.)

When the number of persons on board exceeds the lifeboat limit due to joining of extra crew, supercargo etc., the family member must disembark at Officer’s cost.

Under normal circumstances, the spouse must accompany children. Only under special circumstances can children embark alone. The minimum age of children to sail on board is 12 months. The relevant safety equipment for children/infants must be available on board.

Family members are normally not allowed to join:

  • During crew member’s probationary period
  • During the first voyage of a ship under FFM
  • A newly built ship during the first 3 months after delivery

Family members may visit in port subject to Master’s approval. The Company considers family members as guests with regard to victualling while on board.

Joining family members may make their own travel arrangements or ask the Company to arrange on their behalf. The Company forwards flight details to port agent for transportation arrangements.

The officer bears all joining / leaving expenses for family members. These include, but are not limited to:

  • Flight tickets
  • Launch fees
  • Taxi fees
  • Hotel expenses
  • Port agent fees
  • Immigration charges
  • Medical costs
  • Insurance costs

Expenses are deducted from the Officer’s Wage Account prior to sign off.

Other non-working supernumeraries are responsible for all the expenses related to their stay on board, including joining / leaving expenses.

Standard of accommodation and meals

Accommodation of family members is in Owner’s or other cabins of a similar standard, if available. They will receive the same level of cabin cleaning, laundry etc. as officers. No special meal arrangements should be made for family members, who will normally eat in the officers’ mess.

Third party personnel

  • Continue Numbering
  1. Prior to joining, third party personnel must:
    • Sign the Indemnity Form
    • Have:
      • Valid identification
      • Passport / visas as required
  1. The Master:
    • Collects passports and retains until personnel disembarks
    • Ensures:
      • On board safety familiarisation is conducted within 8 hours or prior to sailing
      • A familiarisation checklist is signed by each person
Note Refer to the on board familiarisation procedures.
  • Records number of additional meals served in the Owners Account in PAL.
  • Informs FFM of embarkation and disembarkation

Relief planning

The Master:

  1. Collects from crew members:
    • Relief requests
    • DoA for next contract
    • DoA for training
  1. Submits Vacation, Relief and Training Planner to FPO by the end of next month
  2. Plans crew relief together with FPO

Contract extension

  1. Crew member obtains approval from Head of Department (HoD) for extension
  2. Crew member submits written extension request to Master for approval
  3. Master sends approved request to FPO
  4. FPO informs the Master of the decision
Note 

FPO will review the request based on future planning and the crew member’s performance.

Early relief requests

  1. Crew member submits to the Master a signed written leave request stating reason
  2. Master:
    • Reviews the request considering:
      • Crew member's length of service on board
      • Ship’s schedule and location
      • Crew member's performance
      • Reason for early relief request
    • Forwards approved request to FPO
Note The crew member may be responsible for proportional relief costs and must agree to the deduction from the wage account.

Transfer to another ship

  1. Crew member submits written transfer request to Master for approval
  2. Master forwards request to FFM for approval
  3. Master ensures:
    • Receipt of correct Final Wage Account including all deductions
    • Return of all original documents to the seafarer
  1. Crew member takes their work clothes to the next ship
Note FFM may request transfers in urgent cases.

Emergency relief

  1. Master ensures completion of Medical Examination Report including:
    • Statement “unfit for work”
    • Statement “to be repatriated”
    • Full legible diagnosis from attending doctor
  1. Master informs FFM
  2. For injury cases, Master submits to FFM:
    • Accident Report
    • Appropriate log book extracts
    • Other supporting documentation
  1. For emergency disembarkation while on passage, Master retains records of:
    • Radio medical advice
    • Treatment and diagnosis
    • Medication
  1. Master ensures:
    • Sign off documents indicate disembarkation on medical grounds
    • Personal items left behind are listed and stored securely until FFM gives further instructions
Note  A senior officer must be present when making the list. A senior officer signs the list to verify accuracy.

Hospitalisation / repatriation

  1. Master:

    • Informs local agent of requirement to transport injured or ill crew member to a hospital 

    • Master informs P&I when required

    • Ensure transfer of injured or ill crew member as agreed

    • Requests agent to countersign any invoices

    • Confirms arrangements of transfer with agents

  1. Master informs FPO immediately of:
    • Name and rank of crew member
    • Nature of illness or injury
    • Details of hospital
    • Repatriation requirement
    • Port and date of disembarkation
    • Port to arrange replacement
  1. Master instructs the local agent to keep P&I representative and FFM informed of:
    • Crew member’s condition
    • Arrangements made
    • Expenses incurred
Note  A senior officer must be present when making the list. A senior officer signs the list to verify accuracy.
  1. Master submits Medical Examination Report and any other doctors’ reports to FPO
  2. If Crew member signs off. Master 
    • Prepares final wage account
    • Ensures that personal items left behind are listed and stored securely until FFM gives further instructions
Note Master may consider paying cash advance. Cash advance may not exceed the crew member’s wage balance unless agreed by FFM.

Dentist / doctor visit (non- urgent)

  1. Master:
    • Informs local agent of requirement to transport crew member to dentist or doctor
    • Confirms arrangements of transfer with agents
    • Requests agent to countersign any invoices
    • Ensure transfer of crew member as agreed
    • Master informs P&I when required
  1. Master informs FFM immediately of:
    • Name and rank of crew member
    • Nature of visit
    • Details of hospital
    • Port
  1. Master submits Medical Examination Report and any other doctors’ reports to FPO

3. Marine Personnel 

3.7 Leave Management 

Shore leave

Shore leave may be granted as long as the safety and security of the ship are not compromised. The decision to grant shore leave is entirely at the Master’s discretion, who must take into account:

  • Agreement by Head of Department (HoD)
  • Work load and requirement for available personnel
  • Adequate manning for port duties
  • Availability of emergency response team at all times

The number of crew granted shore leave must never exceed 50% of the total crew. Actual number of crew on board must be known at all times. All crew members must return to the ship by the time agreed with the HoD and clearly be made aware of the ship’s planned departure time.

The following ranks should not take shore leave at the same time:

  • Master and Chief Officer
  • Chief Engineer and Second Engineer

Study leave

Officers who have completed 12 months of sea service with the Company may submit a written request for study leave to the FP Department. Study leave is granted at the discretion of the Company.

Compassionate relief

The Company will contact the ship on receipt of urgent personal news. Compassionate Relief cases are defined as death or serious illness of:

  • Spouse
  • Dependent parent
  • Dependent child

Any other cases will require an Early Relief request.

In proven compassionate cases, the Company will make every effort to arrange an early relief at the next suitable port subject to safe manning of the ship. The Company will decide who will bear the costs of the relief, depending on the circumstances.

3. Marine Personnel

3.8 Disciplinary Process
Caution:

An appropriate shore manager shall be appointed to consider the crew member's future 

employment and evaluate the case in the light of the dismissal from the ship .
Note When a crew member’s performance or conduct does not  meet FFM standards, the HoD may issue an informal verbal warning.

Informal verbal warning

  1. HoD issues verbal warning with clear explanation of:
    • Offence, incompetence, inefficiency or misconduct
    • Expected improvement or change in conduct
    • Deadline for the improvement or change in conduct

Formal verbal warning

Note When a crew member repeats a minor offence or commits a more serious offence, the Master may issue a formal verbal warning.

The Master:

  1. Issues verbal warning with clear explanation of:
    • Offence, incompetence, inefficiency or misconduct
    • Expected improvement or change in conduct
    • Deadline for the improvement or change in conduct
  1. Records warning in logbook
Note  When additional measures beyond a verbal warning are required, conduct a disciplinary hearing.

Disciplinary hearing

Caution: Do not issue a written warning or dismissal notice without first conducting a disciplinary hearing.
  1. The Master:
    • Issues “ Notice of Disciplinary Hearing” form to crew member
Note Give the notice 24 hours prior to the hearing, when feasible, but no less than 12 hours.
  • Informs crew member of his / her right to bring a fellow crew member to the hearing as support / witness
  • Informs FPO and Head of Crewing about planned hearing
  1. Master conducts the hearing:
    • At least one Senior Officer must attend to:
      • Act as a witness
      • Take notes using the “ Disciplinary Hearing Record” form
    • Master repeats offer to bring a fellow crew member
    • Senior Officer records offer and crew member’s response
    • Master clearly explains and ensures recording of:
      • Reason for the hearing
      • Details of the offence including the date, time and nature
      • Relevant Contract / CBA clause / regulation / policy breached
      • All evidence
    • Master confirms and ensures recording of crew member’s clear understanding of the allegations
    • A senior officer records crew member’s reply to the allegations
    • Master gives crew member opportunity to:
    • Master evaluates all statements and evidence presented
Note 

Evidence can include statements from other crew members before or during the hearing.

  • Master ensures compliance with:
  • Contract of Employment (CoE)
  • Applicable CBA
  • Master chooses:
  • No offence committed
  • Verbal warning
  • Written warning (first / final)
  • Dismissal
  • Master clearly explains and records outcome of the hearing
  • All parties present sign the “Disciplinary Hearing Record” form
  1. Master completes “ Written Warning” or “ Notice of Dismissal” form as required
Note  Clearly refer to previous verbal or written warnings given to the crew member.
  1. Master gives crew member:
    • Copy of the “Disciplinary Hearing Record” form
    • Original of “Written Warning” or “Notice of Dismissal”
  1. Master informs FPO about outcome of the hearing
  1. Master records in logbook:
    • Reason for the hearing
    • Names of all present
    • Outcome
  1. Master sends to FPO:
    • Copy of “Disciplinary Hearing Record”
    • Supporting documents / evidence
    • Copies of “Written Warning” or “Notice of Dismissal” as appropriate
    • Copy of the logbook entry
  1. Master gives a copy of the “Disciplinary Hearing Record” to:
    • The crew member
    • HoD
    • FPO
  1. Master files original “Disciplinary Hearing Record” on board

Written Warning

Caution: Hold a disciplinary hearing before issuing a written warning.
  1. Master issues written warning with clear explanation of:
    • Offence, incompetence, inefficiency or misconduct
    • Expected improvement or change in conduct
    • Deadline for the improvement or change in conduct
    • Previous verbal or written warnings
    • Type of warning:
      • First
      • Final
Note The final written warning must include a statement that the crew member will be dismissed in case of repeated misconduct.

Dismissal

Caution: Hold a disciplinary hearing before issuing a notice of dismissal.

The Master:

  • Continue Numbering
  1. Ensures compliance with:
    • CoE
    • Applicable CBA
Note  The COE and the applicable CBA override FFM guidelines.
  1. Records dismissal as sign off reason in:
    • Final Appraisal
    • Final Wage Account
    • Service Record
  1. Ensures Final Appraisal scoring does not contradict the reason for dismissal
Note Inform FPO and DPA immediately when an offence justifies a dismissal without notice. A hearing is mandatory in all dismissal cases.
  1. Coordinates repatriation/reliever with FPO
Caution: Master and Shore Manager shall refer to the " Code of Conduct for the Merchant Navy"

3. Marine Personnel 

3.9  MLC Complaints

Maritime Labour Convention

Either the Flag administration or the Recognised Organisation (RO, usually the Class Society of the ship) carry out MLC 2006 inspections. The fleet team arranges the inspections and advises the Master well in advance. The fleet team arranges renewal inspections in intervals not exceeding five years. Flag or RO conduct intermediate inspections in the third year after issuing the certificate.

Complaints by a crewmember

  1. Master ensures:
    • Availability of MLC Complaint Contacts in common areas, which must include:
      • Contact details of Flag State and Local Admin - FPM 68 - MLC Flag and National Contacts
      • Shore Contact Details
      • On board representative details
    • All crew have a copy and are aware of this procedure “Complaints by Crew Member “
    • Use of MLC Complaint Tracking form
  1. Crew member addresses complaint, as appropriate, to:
    • Immediate supervisor
    • HoD
    • Master
    • FFM
    • Flag state
Note Address complaints to the lowest possible level of authority within 5 days of the occurrence, but crew members have the right to address any higher level directly.
  1. Crew member refers to the next higher level if complaint is not resolved within the defined time limits
  2. When complaint reaches his / her level, the Master:
    • Holds an investigation
    • Reviews terms and conditions of employment
    • Consults with DPA when necessary
    • Forwards complaint to contact person in FFM if not resolved on board within 10 days
    • Waits for resolution proposed by FFM
    • Decides on:
      • Acceptance of proposed resolution
      • Proposing alternative resolution
      • Referral to flag state
    • Ensures:
      • Completion of MLC complaint tracking form
      • Crew member receives copy of all complaint documents
      • Recording of complaint in logbook
      • Filing of complaint documents

Complaints by third party against crew member

  1. DPA requests Master to explain / investigate the complaint
  2. Master reports findings to DPA
  3. DPA decides on appropriate response, which could be:
    • No further action required
    • Investigation by HSE Department
      • HSE Department notifies complainant and Master of the findings / actions following the investigation

3. Marine Personnel 

3.10 Missing Person

Missing persons, Company actions

In the event of a missing person, the Company will:

  • Coordinate with the relevant authorities and the Master to locate the missing person
  • Coordinate with the Crew Service Centre (CSC) to inform next of kin
  • Notify P&I

In the event of a missing person at sea, Emergency Response Procedures will apply.

In case of proven desertion any balance of wages will be retained by the Company to offset incurred expenses.

Missing person – at sea

The Master:

  1. Orders an immediate and thorough search of the ship
  2. Prepares ship for sea search
  3. Refers to Emergency Response Manual for further action

Missing person – in port

Caution: Do not use the term “deserter” unless there is factual evidence of an act of desertion..

The Master:

  1. Orders an immediate and thorough search of the ship
  2. Questions other persons on board
  3. Immediately informs:
    • FFM
    • Port agent
    • Local P&I representative
Note  Inform local immigration when reasonably certain that missing person deliberately failed to re-join.
  1. Follows the advice of P&I and local authorities
  2. Ensures that personal items left behind are listed and stored securely until FPO gives further instructions
Note A senior officer must be present when making the list. A senior officer signs the list to verify accuracy.
  1. Gives crew member’s documents to local port agent
Note Do not delay sailing unless shore authorities detain the ship. Ensure the ship complies with the Safe Manning Certificate.
  1. Obtains approval from local immigration before sailing
  2. Records all activities in the logbook and sends a copy to FFM
  3. Prepares Final Wage Account

3. Marine Personnel 

3.11 Crew Accounting and Provisions

Wage accounts

Wages are calculated on the basis of 30 days per month. Wages for part of a month are calculated as:

Monthly wages / 30 x number on days on board during that month = pro-rated monthly wage

Note   Submit Final Wage deductions and overtimes 48 hours prior to sign off. Submit Monthly Wage deductions and overtimes to Global Service Centre (GSC) by the end of the month.

The Master:

  • Enters earnings / deductions / overtime into PAL system
  • Finalises the payroll in PAL
  • Clicks the “Send to Office” button
  • Obtains GSC confirmation
  • Verifies Monthly / Final Wage Account
  • Reports errors to GSC for correction
  • Prints Monthly / Final Wage Accounts
  • Obtains each crew member’s signature on his / her Wage Account
Note  Inform GSC of any cash payments to off-signers.

Allotments

Note GSC remits allotments by the 23rd of each month, based on the information provided on the Standing Allotment form prior joining.

The Master:

  • Sends cancellation requests before the 15th of each month
  • Informs GSC immediately of changes to bank details
  • Ensures there is enough money in the crew member’s account balance to cover the cost of the allotment
Caution: Crew members must pay full charges for any rejected payments due to incorrect bank details.
Note   Send request for Special Allotment to GSC. Crew members are allowed one Special Allotment per contract. Charges may apply to any additional special allotments.

Home Allotments

The Company pays a crew member’s monthly home allotment to one bank account only. If the crew member wishes to have payment into more than one bank account, additional charges may be applied.

Crew members who join within the first two weeks of a month may submit an individual home allotment request until the 14th of the month.

Under Philippine law, Filipino crew must remit at least 80% of their basic monthly wage to an account in the Philippines. This does not apply for the month of joining or leaving a ship.

Communication account

The Master ensures:

  • Accurate accounting of personnel communication costs
  • Reporting of amounts to be deducted from individual wage accounts
  • Crew members’ acknowledgement of expenses incurred
Note Communication providers may have specific reporting procedures and requirements.

Recreation fund

The Fleet Personnel (FP) Department advises the fleet of the recreation fund contribution amount. The allowance is to be used to purchase material for the recreation and welfare of all crew members. The purchase of pornographic materials and pirated CDs, DVDs, and software is prohibited.

Masters must ensure accurate accounting of expenditures using the recreation fund accounting form. No amount from this fund is to be paid to individuals as a bonus for assistance with the administration of the recreation accounts or any other reason.

Requests for purchases, repair and / or replacement of recreational items outside the scope of the Recreation Fund must be sent to the Technical Superintendent.

Cash account

The Master:

  • Prepares the Ship´s Cash Account form
  • Stamps and signs Cash Account form at the end of the month
Note  At handover, leaving Master must stamp and sign the Cash Account form and joining Master must countersign.
  • Submits Cash Account form via email to GSC at the end of the month

Cash to Master

Caution: Store cash in ship´s safe only. The Master must keep the key in his possession at all times. This is mandatory for insurance purposes.

Master:

  • Sends request for cash to FPO at least 5 days in advance stating:
  • Port / Date
  • Amount (Minimum 5,000 USD)
  • Currency
  • Breakdown of the denominations required
  • Current cash box balance
  • Confirms receipt of cash within 48 hours to FPO, including:
  • Port / Date
  • Amount
Note  Cash box amount should not exceed the insured limit, as outlined in the Cash to Master (CTM) confirmation.

Cash advance to crew member

  1. Crew member requests cash advance from Master
  2. The Master:
    • Verifies sufficient balance in crew member´s Monthly / Final Wage Account form
    • Updates the Ship´s Cash Account form

Provisioning

The crew is entitled to receive well balanced meals of sufficient quality and quantity. This will be provided free of charge during the period of engagement by the Company. As far as possible ships will be provided with adequate fresh provisions of milk, tea, coffee, vegetables and fruits.

Note 

Refer to Seachef PAL Manual

  1. Chief Cook:
    • Checks quality and quantities of supplied goods
    • Rejects:
      • Wrong deliveries
      • Poor quality goods
  1. Master:
    • Informs TO immediately of any rejected goods or shortages
    • Informs TO about final invoice amount
    • Sends supplier evaluation sheet to TO

Slop chest and bonded stores

Note Master may delegate responsibility for Slop Chest / Bonded Stores to a crew member. 
  1. Sell at purchase price plus 10% commission
  2. Provide 10% commission to crew member nominated to manage the Slop chest / Bonded store
  3. Complete Slop Chest Account form

  4. Record amount transferred to the wage account of the nominated crew member on Monthly Cash Account form

  5. Master: 

    • Prepares, stamps and signs Slop Chest Account form at the end of the month
    • Submits Slop Chest Account form via email to GSC at the end of the month
Note  At handover, leaving Master must prepare, stamp and sign the Slop Chest Account. Joining Master must countersign.

Local purchasing – cash payment

Note  Do not arrange local purchases via local agents.
  1. The Master:
    • Sends permission request to Technical Officer (TO) stating:
      • Type / quantity of goods
      • Intended port of purchase
      • Estimated costs
    • Obtains:
      • TO permission
      • Receipt for purchase
    • Forwards receipt copy stating ship name to TO
    • Attaches receipt copy to monthly provision account
Note In exceptional cases, the Master may spend a maximum of USD 500 per month without prior approval.

3. Marine Personnel

3.13 Crew insurance

FFM provides the Crew Protection and Indemnity (P&I) insurance. Coverage is provided during the normal course of duty. The Contract of Employment states FFM’s responsibilities towards a crew member.

  • The P&I coverage includes:
  • Medical expenses as defined in the Contract of Employment
  • Injury / loss of life compensation
  • Repatriation expenses of sick / injured crew (including deviation expenses)
  • Relieving crew member’s travel expenses
  • Immigration fines, accommodation and repatriation of stowaways
  • Immigration fines for deserters
  • Crew member’s personal effects as defined in the Contract of Employment
Note Non-insured articles are cash (except by special arrangement with the employer), valuables, watches, jewellery, radios, or any other articles which P&I club consider non-essential for crew members to perform their duties.

Spectacles and Dental Treatment

Crew members must pay for their own spectacles and artificial teeth. Accidental damage caused during official duties will be covered by FFM. The Master must inform FFM office about the circumstances of any claims.

Essential dental treatment is covered. Cosmetic treatment is excluded unless necessary following an accident during official duties.

War Risk Insurance

War Risk Area coverage is provided under the owner’s insurance arrangements. The details of the coverage are outlined in the Contract of Employment.

          Instructions

          • Create a mongoDB script file name as "Update.js"
          • Place each script in a seperate folder
          • Create a folder for each script and folder name should be digit ("01 , 02")
            • Create folder name as "01" and copy the script file into this folder
            • Create folder name as "02" and copy the another script file into this folder
            • One folder should contain only one script file
          • Finaly copy these folders into location /UtilityFiles/AutoUpdaterScript/Vessel under the VesselIntegrator API build path

          Instructions

          • Create a mongoDB script file name as "Update.js"
          • Place each script in a seperate folder
          • Create a folder for each script and folder name should be vessel objectID ("84524" , "865050")
            • Create folder name as "865050" and copy the script file into this folder
            • Create folder name as "84524" and copy the another script file into this folder
            • One folder should contain only one script file
          • Finaly copy these folders into location /UtilityFiles/VesselScript/ under the VesselIntegrator API build path

          Instructions

          • Create a mongoDB script file name as "Update.js"
          • Place each script in a seperate folder
          • Create a folder for each script and folder name should be vessel TypeID ("1234" , "8585")
            • Create folder name as "1234" and copy the script file into this folder
            • Create folder name as "8585" and copy the another script file into this folder
            • One folder should contain only one script file
            • It will replicate to all vessel under this vessel TypeID
          • Finaly copy these folders into location if its passenger type then copy to /UtilityFiles/VesselTypeScript/Pass/ for normal ship /UtilityFiles/VesselTypeScript/Vessel/ under the VesselIntegrator API build path
